titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Loring Austin called upon me this morning for a Passport, and offering to take letters for America, for which he is about to embark— I gave him a letter for the Secretary of State, and requested him to call before his final departure for other letters which he promised me he would do— The weather was so bad that it confined me almost the whole day at home; and the Evening was entirely without Company— It was only this day that I finished a letter begun the day before yesterday; for I find myself writing more and more slow as I advance— In the Evening however I began another letter; and in the mean time this Journal falls continually in arrears— Whenever something urgent occurs to be done, I postpone the morning record of every preceding day which is my theoretical principle; and whenever the day has left behind it much to be recorded I am too apt to put off beginning it by a sort of instinctive aversion to the labour which I see must be performed—when both these incidents occur together the dilatory weakness increases, and the arrears accumulate, untill the occurrences which should be noted down have escaped from my memory— I am now writing the first day of October’s Journal on the sixth, and sometimes though not often run behind still more. But of a day past in writing there can be little to say— The writing itself might serve for a Journal.

2. Mr Montreal paid me a visit this morning, and made me a proposition for the employment of a certain sum of money—that is to discount two bills of ten thousand Roubles each for six per Cent; the bills having yet four months to run—that is at 1 1/2 per Cent per Month— But not being satisfied with this mode of transacting business, I declined the proposal. I had some time since asked him if he could inform me whether such a Sum could be employed to advantage, with the intention of drawing all that I am authorized to draw, that I might be prepared for the political contingencies which may render it impossible to draw upon Holland at-all— But I prefer waiting to this. The day was again rainy and stormy untill Sunset, when it cleared away— Mr Craig came to take leave, on his return to Vienna.

3. The first part of the day was again bad, and the Evening fair— I was making up my quarterly Account and then writing to the Secretary of State;—which detained me untill so near five O’Clock that I could take before dinner only one turn upon the Boulevard near our door— After dinner I took three— Mr Patterson and Mr Blodget spent part of the Evening with us— Mr Patterson, is going in two or three days, again for Archangel— Although the last week I have been so steadily busy, that my time has seldom been so laboriously spent, my Journal has continued to fall in arrears— Excepting our Company last Monday I have had nothing to divert me from my studies and duties; yet I have not kept pace with them— Mrs Adams and Catherine went into the City this morning; and began the removal of our furniture. The Country has become unpleasant to all the family except myself— I shall regret it, the whole Winter— I read in the Evening a little of the Edinburgh Review.

4. Finished reading the second Volume of the Bibliothéque des Philosophes, containing the Commentary of Hierocles, upon the golden verses, translated by Dacier, with his own reflections upon it. Hierocles lived in the fifth Century of the Christian AEra, and though not himself a Christian, his book contains unequivocal proof of the influence of Christian Doctrines and principles upon the moral and religious Spirit of his age— The perusal of these Volumes has given me a little further insight into the history, character and doctrines of Pythagoras.— His symbols were probably borrowed from Egypt, and may be considered as an intermediate stage between hieroglyphical and alphabetical writing. As maxims of morality, the advantage of symbols is that of impressing upon the memory the moral precept, by the association of ideas, and by bringing the sense of the duty frequently to the mind, through the instrumentality of sensible images— It was the principle of the Pythagoricians that the symbol was to be observed both in its literal and in its mystical meaning—but the literal precept was often frivolous; its connection with the moral duty, obscure, uncertain, or ambiguous; and the moral duty itself not always important.— The golden Verses contain the foundation of a system of Theology and of Morality, in the style of authoritative precepts, and without symbols.— It is refined and pure as theology, as far as was attainable by Heathens before the Christian Revelation— Its morality was founded upon the Cardinal virtues, which are fully set forth by Hierocles and the whole basis properly laid in Piety—the first and greatest of the Virtues is Justice, which includes in itself the three others, Prudence, Temperance and Fortitude— The doctrine of self-examination every Night, and self-preparation every morning is taught in these verses, and is doubtless highly useful— The Pythagoricians made a practice of repeating these verses themselves every Night, and morning— The necessity of prayer and action in concurrence, for the success of all undertakings, is also here forcibly inculcated, and of excellent use— I hope to have occasion to recur to this Book again.— We sent this day the first Boat-load of our furniture into the City. We dined with Count St: Julien the Austrian Minister, at a great diplomatic dinner— The first he has given— Count Romanzoff, the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin, the two Masters of the Ceremonies, Laval and Maisonneuve— The French Ambassador, his Aid, Secretaries and Consul, and all the other foreign Ministers and their Secretaries were there, excepting Count Maistre the Sardinian, and the Chevalier Bezerra the Portuguese Minister— The absence of these Gentlemen, with both of whom Count St: Julien is well acquainted, and who are always invited to Count Romanzoff’s parties, was evidence clear enough of Austrian policy, and how its pride cowers before the power of France— There was in the dinner, and in every thing connected with it, an effort of magnificence, seemingly to equal or outdo that of the French Ambassador— The Servants were nearly as numerous, and in the same various styles of liveries, and equally rich— But the Count had behind his own Chair two Chasseurs in hussar-dresses, bedizined with silver lace and tassels and sashes to such a degree that scarcely any part of the cloathing under them was visible— Their mantles bordered with furs, hung cross wise behind them from shoulder to shoulder, and both of them were tall handsome men, with persons well adapted to set off their garments. This is a very handsome dress; but not more convenient than suitable to a footman waiting at dinner behind a gentleman’s Chair— The Count’s house is also very magnificently furnished—he gives for it two thousand ducats a year rent— His table was handsomely ornamented, but not so superbly as is customary at the Chancellor’s, or at the Ambassador’s— His dinner was remarkable for a number of things, of studied rarity, such as pine-apple jelly served in cups of pine-apple rinds— There was a band of music performing during the dinner almost without intermission— The music was very good, but fit only for the field— The horns, and drums, and cymbals, made such a thundering harmony, that it was literally rending with tremendous noise our ears asunder— It was impossible to hold any Conversation with one’s next neighbour— General Pardo told me after dinner that the only way he had been able to account for its not having been stop’d after the first three minutes by order of the master of the house was that his cartilages were ossified. The Count was indeed the only person at table who did not appear sensible at all that his orchestra was too powerful— The Emperor Francis’s health was drank in Champaign, the company all rising from table according to the usage at the Chancellor’s and at the Ambassador’s— But it was curious that Count Romanzoff after going through the Ceremony of this toast, addressed himself before he sat down, across Count St: Julien to the Ambassador who sat on the other side of him, and toasted his Master, the Emperor Napoleon— This was another act of homage to the Supremacy of France, demonstrative of Russian policy.— For this dinner was occasional—given on the Emperor Francis’s name-day; and the honour was intended exclusively for him— Count Romanzoff never thinks of the Emperor Francis, at his Alexander day dinners or at the Napoleon day fêtes at the Ambassador’s— The attendance of the Servants like every thing else at this dinner bespoke the stiffness and aukwardness of novelty, and even the seating of the Company was irregular and unusual— The Chevalier de Sturmer sat at the Ambassador’s left hand— Almost all the foreign Ministers sat on the opposite side of the table. I sat between Count Bussche and the Chevalier de Bray.
I observed the rule of temperance better than usual at these great dinners, to which I believe the stunning noise of the music in some sort contributed— For by preventing all conversation it left my mind unoccupied by any thing which could lead me to forget my resolution, and by confusing the brain it roused me to an extraordinary exertion to preserve it in as rational a State as was possible. The company all retired immediately after dinner and I came home with a dull head-ache occasioned by the noise, but which subsided, as soon as I had enjoyed half an hour of quiet at home— In the Evening, I got engaged with a number of the Edinburgh Review, which insensibly carried me till between one and two in the morning, before I perceived it was bed-time— I had a morning visit from Mr Ecky and Mr Harris junior.

5. Began reading the third Volume of the Bibliothéque des Philosophes— I shall now take up Plato— Mr Bowers came to ask me for a Passport which I gave him— Mr Montréal also paid me a Morning visit— The day being remarkably fine, a favour at this season of the year very rare, I allowed a large part of it to bodily exercise. Walked round over the Wyburg Bridge, and over the two Bridges at Kammenoi-Ostroff; my grand tour, which I performed probably for the last time— It is a walk of more than two hours— After dinner I walked again, nearly an hour— The sky was unusually clear, and the Comet which has now got above the head of the great-Bear, brighter than I had yet seen it.— After returning home I made an extract from the Edinburgh Review, relative to the Hindu Mythology; and all the rest of the Evening was engaged in packing up books and papers, and removing desks and book-cases from my Cabinet to be sent into the City to-morrow.

6. Morning visit from Mr Harris, and Evening one, from Mr Ernestus Plummer and Mr Loring Austin— I gave this Gentleman the letters I have been preparing for America; he intends going down to Cronstadt to-morrow. The second Boat-load of our furniture was sent into the City; and I employed all that was left of the morning in retrieving the arrears of my Journal, without accomplishing it entirely. Walked to the Summer Garden Bridge and over it before dinner— Began a letter to George in the Evening— Read Robinson’s character of St: Peter and a Sermon in the English Preacher, upon the impossibility of concealing Sin. Among the wants which my letters to George make me sensibly feel, is that of the Hebrew language, for the sake of reading the Scriptures in the Original.

7. I retrieved at last all the arrears of my Journal; but it is at the expence of my letter writing— The ladies were the greater part of the morning in the City, to which it is our purpose to remove to-morrow— I walked before dinner over Count Strogonoff’s Garden, of which I now take my leave, and which has afforded me a frequent and agreeable walk, the summer through— I examined again the antient tomb, said sometimes to be that of Homer, and sometimes that of Achilles.— It is of marble—eight feet long 44. inches high, and of the same width— The four sides are sculptured in Basso-relievo— At the East end is a Centaur, with a bow, and a young man naked; the two faces are directed each towards the other, and it seems intended to represent the training of Achilles by the Centaur Chiron— The long North side has four figures representing two Centaurs in battle one with a lion, and the other with a lioness or tyger— In the centre and behind the animals there is a tree. On the short West side is a female figure seated, playing upon a lyre, and two others standing, one on each side of her— The long South side has ten human figures of which two are women seated upon stools—in the centre is a young Man with a shield upon his arm, in an attitude of starting to force himself away, and a female on her knees before him as if imploring him to stay— I conjecture it to be Achilles discovered by Ulysses, and summoned to attend the Greeks at the siege of Troy— The sculpture is in a style of very considerable refinement, but not of the most perfect period of the Art— The heads of the Centaurs, the form of the naked young-man, and of the Lions, and the draperies of all the attired figures are executed in a style of great improvement— There are mouldings and Cornices above and below the figures round three of the sides, but the long side with the two Centaurs and lions is plain— At three of the Corners are carved plain Doric Pilasters, but at the fourth the Eastern Corner is an image like a human figure with the head of an Ape— There is a marble lid or cover, originally of the same length and width as the tomb, but one end of which has been broken off; it still however nearly covers the whole—it is shaped like the roof of an American Barn, sharp pointed at the top, as if to shed with most ease the snow or rain— It is uniformly sculptured in a sort of regular leaves and is too feet in perpendicular height— On the face of its unbroken end there is a round medallion carved in the stone upon which there may have been an inscription— There is not however at present the trace of a letter— The sides of the monument themselves are not entire—they have been broken in several places, but are put
together again with accurate adaptation— As I was returning home I met Nelson, who told me that the Emperor would return into the City for the winter to-morrow— Passing by the Ambassadors I saw the people carrying furniture to a boat from his house; also for the purpose of removal— It was too late after dinner for my Evening walk— I employed the Evening in continuing my letter to George, teaching Charles to read, and reading the Edinburgh Review.

8. We sent off this morning the third and last boat of our furniture, and removed also ourselves into the City— I had morning visits from Mr Roberts and Mr Rogers, and also from Mr Woodward— He met me just as I was leaving the house, and walked with me into the City— I came into the new Apartments that we are to occupy, about four O’Clock— We had a late dinner, and I did not leave the house the remainder of the day— I partly arranged my furniture and papers, but left much to be done to-morrow. Amused the leisure of the Evening by reading in the Bibliotheque des Philosophes, and the Edinburgh Review.— I quit with reluctance the house in the Country, which is convenient, and has a delightful situation, and where I have spent three Months very agreeably— But all my family except myself were tired of it, and the season rendered the removal expedient, and perhaps necessary. Our new abode is at the Corner of the Vosnesenskoi, or () and the little Officer’s Streets; within five minute’s walk of the house where we formerly resided and which Mr Plincke has sold— I am to give for it 5000 Rubles a year rent, including two hundred fathoms, or Sajenes of white birch wood, at ten Rubles the Sajene— This measure is seven feet long and as high, the wood being on the average eighteen inches long— It contains therefore 73 1/2 cubic feet, which is fifteen Sajenes to eight Cords— My calculation was that 200 Sajenes, being about 110 Cords would last us untill next June when I expect we shall leave this Country— But we have consumed forty Sajenes in three Months, two of which were Summer Months, and the third merely the Commencement of Autumn— My New land lord attempted to persuade me to engage for only 150 Sajenes—he said the house could not require more, or at the utmost 160— But I know that would be fallacious— If the 200 last us untill June it will be more than I now expect.

div.p:
9. We were highly favoured in the weather, for the removal of our furniture; the three days upon which we sent the boats having passed entirely without rain— This day there was a constant rain from noon untill our dining hour, which confined me altogether to the house— I employed it in putting up my books and arranging my papers— I scarcely wrote at all; but read more than usual— Finished the third Volume of the Bibliothéque des Philosophes— It contains a Dedication to the king by Dacier—a Discourse upon Plato; with some Account of the motives for the Translation— A Life of Plato— Dissertations upon the Doctrine—the Style and Method,—and the Interpreters and Commentators of Plato— The first Alcibiades, or concerning Human Nature; and the second Alcibiades, or upon Prayer— Voltaire says that Dacier was a mule loaded with all antiquity— There appears to be neither criticism nor philosophy in his own writings— I have not the means of judging of the merit of his translations; but they are in no high repute— It is strange that a man who had spent so much time and taken such pains to understand Plato himself, and to make him understood by others, should have caught so little of his Spirit himself— He has a profound Admiration both of Plato and of Socrates; but it is the admiration of a slave, or of an inferior being— His great anxiety seems to be, to make Saints of them— Yet I am under obligations to him for making me acquainted with Socrates and Plato;—whom I have either not Greek enough, or not leisure enough to read in the original— I read the first Alcibiades at Auteuil in 1784. or 1785. and it has been useful to me— The second Alcibiades might be called the Vanity of Human Wishes— It lays down the same principles, and uses the same Arguments as Juvenal and Dr Johnson have thrown into the poetical and satyrical form— The form of prayer recommended by Socrates is more comprehensive than that of Juvenal, and contains the substance of a part of the Lord’s prayer— The process of the Socratic reasoning is slow; sometimes too diffuse; and too uniform in the manner.— Cicero gives some importance to all the personages of his Dialogues— Plato has but one personage; all the rest are automata— I read also several Articles in the Edinburgh Review; and among the rest that upon the philosophical Essays of Dugald Stewart, published at Edinburgh in 1810— The whole Article is curious and highly interesting; but there is one part of it which gave me a mingled sensation of surprize, pleasure and mortification— It is a train of reasoning on the subject of etymology, and figurative language so similar to that of my Lectures 30. 31. and 32. that it would be difficult for a third person, reading both not to suspect one to be a plagiarism from the other—the whole page 198 of the Review (N. 33. for Novr: 1810) is so much like pages 274 and 275. of my second Volume that they seem almost copied from one another.— I was surprized to find opinions and even some of the forms of expression which I had thought entirely my own, belonging as much to another writer as to myself.
I was pleased to find such a coincidence between my own Sentiments and those of so distinguished a writer as Dugald Stewart— And I was mortified to find myself not alone in what I considered as among the few original parts of my book, and upon which my Vanity has often flattered me as with a discovery— I was somewhat unwell this day.

10. I began reading the fourth Volume of the Bibliotheque des Philosophes— We were still occupied with the arrangements of our house— The ladies had a visit from Mrs: Bentzon— Snow, part of the morning— The first of the Season— I walked before dinner to the foundery— On returning home I received a packet from Mr Russell at Paris, enclosing one from Mr J. S. Smith; but none from America— It was brought by a Courier to Count Romanzoff— It contains an account of the discourse held by the Emperor Napoleon to the Russian Ambassador, at the Diplomatic Circle on the 15th: of August.— I still neglected writing this day.

11. Morning visits from Mr Harris, Mr Tatom and Mr Plummer; and in the Evening from Mr Blodget and Mr Hollins— Mr Harris sent me a couple of American Newspapers—containing the Commencement of the answer to Mr R. Smith’s pamphlet, and another spurious forgery under the name of the Duke of Cadore— I began this day, the first since our removal to write; but was obliged to employ the Evening to that purpose— Wrote to the Secretary of State— I walked before dinner to the foundery, and returned by the Newsky Perspective.

12. Before we rose from breakfast this morning I had a visit from Mr Montréal, which was soon followed by one from our landlady’s son, Mr Strugochnikoff— This Gentleman’s object was to receive his half-year’s rent in advance, which I accordingly paid him— He was followed by the Messenger from the Master of Ceremonies, who came with a Card from Count Paul Strogonoff, announcing the death of his father Count Alexander Strogonoff, the old nobleman who had received us at the Consecration of the Cazan Church, as at his home— He had just lived to witness its consecration, and on that day in the Church itself had been elevated by the Emperor to the first Class, of the Subjects of the Empire; in which there were only two persons besides himself—Count Romanzoff, and Prince Kurakin the Ambassador at Paris— He was nearly eighty years of age, and had enjoyed every honour and dignity, and pleasure of life, almost to its last day— It was probably however the fatigue and the chill of the Consecration which cost him his life— His funeral service is to be performed at the Cazan Church on Tuesday next, and to be followed by a procession to the Monastery of St: Alexander Nevsky.— Mr: Samuel Adams Wells, of Boston, a Grandson of the late Governor Adams came with a letter to me, from Mr Erving at Copenhagen— He arrived at Riga, and came from thence as a Courier— And now he cannot go, for some weeks, unless I obtain for him a Courier’s Passport to return— I promised to apply for one for him— I had undertaken to write to my father; but all these interruptions prevented me from finishing it this day; though I wrote late in the Evening— A walk to the foundery was my only exercise.

13. Finished reading the fourth Volume of the Bibliotheque des Philosophes.— It contains the Theages, or on Wisdom— The Eutyphron, or on Holiness— An Abridgment by Dacier of the first and second Alcibiades, and of the Eutyphron— The Apology of Socrates, delivered upon his trial— The Crito, or upon the obligation of Duty—and the Phaedo, upon the immortality of the Soul; which I now read the second time— In the Theages, Socrates gives the account of his Demon or familiar Spirit— A Voice he says, which occasionally warned him what he was not to do, but which never gave him any advice to act— It is not easy to say, whether this was the effect of Superstition, or whether he spoke in figure— It is still more difficult to impute it to deliberate deception.— The instances which he gives of the occasions when he heard the voice, make it hardly possible to consider him, as having intended only Prudence, or Conscience— They are four: but they all relate to the conduct of others and not his own— The Eutyphron is a discussion whether it be consistent with holiness for a man to appear as the accuser of his father for murder— Socrates here mentions that he himself was accused by Melitus of disbelieving the established Gods, and attempting to introduce new ones—he certainly does ridicule the popular creed about the Gods then in repute, and shews that holiness cannot be defined that which pleases them.— The Apology is divided into three parts, what he said before the question upon the charge—after it when he was to name his own punishment—and after the sentence of death had been passed upon him—the mildness of his tone and manner—the firmness and intrepidity of his adherence to his principles, the sportive playfulness of his satire, and the exalted purity of his doctrines, are all but divine— He repeats here the assurance that he is accompanied by a demon; but there is no substantial defence against the accusation of Melitus— He had no defence to make— The charges were substantially true— The Crito, is the
exposition of his motives for refusing to make his escape from prison when under sentence of death— Sublime Morality— Hume I think says it is the Doctrine of passive Obedience and Non-resistance— Socrates argues in this dialogue from a dream that he had had the Night before— So that he believed in dreams— He lays down however and demonstrates the position, that evil is never to be returned for evil, and it is from this that Juvenal quotes that sentiment in his 13th: Satire— I am better pleased with the Phaedo, at the second reading than I was at the first— Its argument is still unsatisfactory— One of his principal reasons is the Doctrine of the Metempsycosis—another the existence of the Soul before the body—which is attempting to prove a doubtful point; by data still more doubtful— We know them now to be false— The idea that Spirit is a simple and not a compound essence, and therefore not liable to decomposition like matter, is ingenious, and the strongest that he gives. He refutes with sufficient force the objection of Simmias that the soul is only a harmony, and that of Cebes that although the Soul may last long enough for several bodies it must at last wear out— But one of the most remarkable things in this Treatise is the observation of Simmias, that to establish firmly the belief of the Soul’s immortality a special revelation from heaven is necessary.— I had visits this morning from Mr: Fisher and Mr Blodget, and the whole Evening was absorbed by visits from Mr and Madam Bezerra, Mr Harris and Mr St. Genest— I was barely able to finish my letter to my father, and to read the Characters of St: John the Evangelist, and of Herod Antipas in Robinson—and two Sermons in the English Preacher; on Sincerity and on Evil-Speaking, both by Tillotson— The first two of the second Volume— The letters to George are again suspended, and although the day was fine I had scarcely time for my walk.

14. Morning Visits from Mr Harris, Mr Woodward, and Mr Saltus, who took up so much of my time, that I was just able to get through a short letter to Mr Erving, to be sent by Mr Wells; and I also wrote to Count Romanzoff for a Passport for him— The Ladies spent the Evening in making visits, and I had Charles with me almost the whole Evening, in my Chamber— I teach him as well as I can to read and speak French— Began this morning upon the fifth volume of the Bibliothéque des Philosophes.

15. Attended the funeral solemnities at the interment of the late Count Strogonoff— We went to his house about half-past nine in the morning— He was lying in State, under a splendid canopy in an apartment hung entirely round with black cloth, and lighted with tapers— All the principal nobility of the Court were there, but none of the foreign Ministers, except Count Maistre— But Mr Laval the Master of the Ceremonies told me that it was considered as more of a Compliment to the family to go first to the house— The corpse was removed from the house in about half an hour— The procession to the Cazan Church was performed entirely on foot, and every body was bare-headed; the house being too near the Church to form a procession of Carriages— The crowd was so great that it was with great difficulty I made my way into the Church, and found it to the place of the foreign Ministers— The Ceremonies were similar to those I had seen at the interment of Prince Beloselsky, but longer, and with more magnificence— There was a funeral discourse, delivered by the Archimandrite Philaretus, said to be the most distinguished Orator among the Russian Clergy— It had the merit of being short—about twenty minutes, but I could not understand him; and few of the assembly could hear him— His manner was temperate and his gestures graceful— He did not appear to attempt any excitement of the Passions— The Passport as it is commonly called is only a prayer for God’s mercy to the deceased, and a sort of Certificate of his character— It is roll’d up and put into the right hand before the closing of the Coffin— The body was clad in the uniform worn by the Count when alive, with the Star of the Order of Saint Andrew upon the Coat— A number of Stools covered with Cushions of Crimson velvet were ranged on both sides of the stage on which the Coffin was placed, and on each stool was laid the mark of some distinction which the Count had enjoyed; such as the ribbands of the different orders; a gold medal struck by the assembly of the Nobility of the Province, of which he had been chosen eight or nine times successively the Marshall &c— Before the Coffin was closed, his Son, Grand-son, relations, friends, and servants went up and performed the usual ceremony of kissing his hand— The Son and Grand-son prostrated themselves three times at the lowest-step before they went up and as they descended— One of the women of the family remained prostrate with her face fixed down upon the first step, for a full space of five minutes, weeping and sobbing aloud as in extreme distress— Countess Litta, who is a distant relation of the deceased, was much affected during part of the deceased ceremony.— She wept much, and
sobbed heavily for some minutes, but recovered herself, before the ceremony was finished— It was past two O’Clock when the procession from the Church commenced; but I did not follow it— I returned home— I had some conversation at the house with Count Romanzoff— I mentioned to him the appearance of French privateers at the passage of the Sound, concerning which I observed I knew that Mr Harris had spoken to him— He said that Mr Gourieff had laid the subject before the Emperor—that the Emperor had directed Mr Gourieff to report the Statement to him the Chancellor, and had directed him to make representations concerning it to the Danish Government, and he had accordingly entered into Correspondence with the Danish Government through Baron Blome, about it— But what could be done? If France had no possessions upon the Baltic, the old ground might be taken that the Baltic was a mare clausum, but however it might be closed with regard to other Nations it could not be so to the powers bordering upon it; and consequently not now to France— I told him that such Considerations had induced me to spare him the trouble of a formal application upon the subject— I had not much expectation from what Denmark would do, though she would be the greatest sufferer by the Event— Our vessels would not go through the Sound to pay the toll, for the sake of being taken by French privateers— They would sooner come with English Convoys through the Belt— The Count said he hoped many of them would take their destination for Archangel, as he did not think they would be troubled by French Privateers in that Sea— And then he told me again, with an injunction to consider him as laying aside the character of Chancellor of the Empire, the Story about the enragés de terre and the enragés de mer, which he had told me before, last June— He asked me, if I had any late news from America; and particularly with reference to a prospect of War, between the United States, and England. I told him I had none— But if I could venture to give him my private opinion, it was that there would not be a War— That France was rendering us too many good Offices, like that of stationing these privateers at the passage of the Sound, to make us very hasty in coming to extremities with England— He smiled and said he thought so too— I told him I had Boston Newspapers to 10. August, by which I found that Count Pahlen was then there— He said he had no letters from him at that place— On returning home I found the Courier’s Passport for Mr Wells, and afterwards received the order for the horses— I carried them to the Hotel de l’Europe, but Mr Wells was not at his lodgings— I paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Bentzon— The lady only received me, Mr Bentzon being unwell— I sat with her about an hour— At the Church door this morning I met Baron Campenhausen, and asked if I could call and see him to morrow morning. He told me that he would be glad to see me, and the place of his present residence— The french Ambassador and the Chevalier de Bray paid us Evening visits

16. Mr Wells and Mr Roberts called upon me this morning— I gave the former of them his Passport and a letter for Mr Erving— But I was not able to finish in time the letter for the Secretary of State that I was also preparing to send by him— Count Bussche the Westphalian Minister paid me a long visit, and told me that Count Schenk the Minister of Wurtemberg was recalled; and a certain Count Frohberg, or Montjoie appointed to take his place— I called upon Mr Fisher and left with him a couple of letters to be sent by Mr Tatem, who goes to-morrow through Sweden, to embark at Gothenburg for America— I afterwards called upon Count St: Julien, and left with him Mr. Russell’s letter to Mr Craig; requesting him to forward it whenever he should have an opportunity, which he promised he would do— The Chevalier de Bray was with him when I went in; but immediately left us— My last visit was to Baron Campenhausen, whom I did not find at home— I spent the Evening at home reading and writing—

17.— Morning visits from Mr Montreal, with Mr Peyron a young Gentleman from Hamburg—next from Commodore Bainbridge and Mr Calhoun—the Commodore informed me that he expected to leave the City next Tuesday or Wednesday; and requested me to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport— Mr: Prevot also called upon me with a letter for Stockholm, which I had promised to send for him, by Mr Tatem— I went with the letter to Mr Fisher’s but did not find him at home.— Walking afterwards upon the quay I met Mr E. Plummer, and Mr Smith of Boston; who informed me of the arrival of several American vessels. Met the Emperor, who asked me if I had returned into the City, and where I lived now— I told him in a corner house of the Vosnesensky and little-Officer’s streets— He said he knew well where it was; and after living thirty-five years in a place he ought to be well acquainted with it— He enquired whether Madame was confined— I told him she had been— When?
More than two months ago— What? in the Country?— In the Country.— He shrugged his shoulders and waved his hand, which is a fashion of gesture that he often uses to intimate that he did not know a thing you are telling him, without saying it— And he does not say it, because he cannot— I believe he knew my wife had been confined, perfectly well— But he asked me the question, for the sake of conversation, and to please me; and after asking it, he could not seem to know any thing about it— His mother does the same thing more remarkably still—he pursued the enquiries—had her confinement been fortunate?— entirely so— And what had she got?— a daughter— He then said he believed I did not walk now so much as formerly— just the same— But said he, we have lived very near each other this Summer, and I do not know how it has happened that we have never met— I said it was true, that it had been long since I had the honour of seeing him— Not once that I recollect, said he, the whole summer— Yet I was often riding and walking— I said I believed the cause of it was, that I had generally been walking at His Majesty’s hour of dinner— He finished by making an observation upon the weather— He said nothing upon any political topic— In the Evening, Madame Colombi, and her sister Frederica were here— We had Conversation— Music— and singing— Mr Fisher, also spent the Evening with us, and informed me that Mr Tatem left the City this afternoon. Mr Wells went yesterday.

18. I was looking over my papers this morning, and found that a number of them were not arranged conformably to my general system— I took them up, and put them in order, but it occupied so much of the morning, that I lost the writing of the day— Mr Saltus called upon me with Mr Lorentz a Citizen of the United States, but a native of Hamburg. He is lately from Sweden, and wants to go to Hamburg, but is afraid of being molested in consequence of the Emperor Napoleon’s new laws against the naturalization of his Subjects in foreign Countries— In the Evening I attempted to read; but was obliged to cease, and give it up almost entirely to idleness, by the weakness of my eyes— I could not write at-all.

19. Mr David and Mr Fisher visited me this morning— Mr David informed me that he intended to go in about ten days for Gothenburg to embark for America, and offered to take letters— Mr Fisher gave me a Fauteuil ticket for the Play, this Evening— I had a visit also from Mr Bentzon, who mentioned of me that he had business here with the American Company, and complained much of their procrastination— I paid a visit to Baron Campenhausen, and applied to him in behalf of Captain Bates of the Mary; on whose Account Mr Saltus has been to me—the Baron told me that the case was very clear, and that he would write so that the business should be settled, not later than to-morrow— I paid also visits to the French Ambassador, to General Pardo, and to the Chevalier de Bray; neither of whom was at home— I then walked untill five— Went after dinner to the Little Theatre, and saw Merope— It is one of the performances of Mademoiselle George, in which I have seen her before— I still think her as an actress far beneath her fame— But Merope is so poor a Tragedy, that the character does injustice to her talents— There is but one good scene in the Play, which is the anagnorisis in the third Act— The Characters are ill drawn and ill-supported, and the action altogether without probability or interest— Miss George was much applauded, and was called out after the Tragedy— There was no after piece; but a dance— It snowed the whole Evening.

20. Finished reading the fifth and last volume of the Bibliothéque des Philosophes, containing the Laches, on Valour— The Protagoras or the Sophists— The rivals, concerning the study of Philosophy— The Hippias Major—concerning the beautiful; and the Euthydemus, translated by M. de Maucroix; and finally the Banquet, translated partly by Racine, and partly by Madame de Rochechouart, but I believe by neither of them completely.— I have been much delighted with this work in general, and have found several excellent principles in almost every one of the Dialogues— If any exception is to be made it respects the Euthydemus, where the Sophists are so outrageously ridiculous, that it is altogether incredible they should have been serious— Every one of these Treatises is of the Destructive kind, that is the whole object of it is to prove the Sophistry of the Sophists— In the Banquet however, Socrates gives his own idea of the Good and Fair, the object of love, and which it would seem he applied as the source of all the Virtues— His reasoning however sometimes resembles too much that of the Sophists.
In the Protagoras the Sophists are most fairly dealt with— There they have at least some Sense and Understanding. The Dialogues are Dramatic—interspersed with incidents which relieve from the dryness of the discussion; and highly characteristic— In the Banquet each of the discourses upon Love is appropriate to the person who delivers it— And they form a Climax of interest in the manner of treating the Subject— Phaedrus is modest and learned— Pausanias fanciful; Eriximachus discusses the matter like a physician, and Aristophanes like a buffoon— Agathon is a sweet enthusiast, and Socrates almost divine— I regret much the omitted part.— I wrote all the morning after breakfast— In the Evening we had visitors. Mr and Madame Rayneval, Madame de Betancourt and her daughters, and Mr Harris— He brought me a letter from my Mother of 24. July— I read the Character of St: Stephen in Robinson, and two Sermons in the English Preacher Vol. 2. on Anger—and on the tendency of Virtue to prolong life.

21— After finishing the Bibliothéque des Philosophes, I find my relish for Socrates and Plato so much increased that I have resolved to read through all the remaining translations from Plato that I possess— I therefore took up this morning the first Volume of the Republic, translated by the Abbé Grou, and read the Preface which is long and principally concerning Socrates— I have heretofore cursorily read the greatest part of these Translations, intending to study Plato in the Original— But much to my Mortification I have never been able to learn Greek enough to read the original, and now I must abandon all hope of ever accomplishing such a task— I must study Translations— I spent much of the forenoon also in examining the Abbé Barthelemi’s Anacharsis to see what he says of Socrates and Plato; it is dispersed over so many of the volumes that I must read them all— I had morning visits from Mr Smith of Boston, with Mr Ingraham and Mr Blanchard, who have just arrived in some of the vessels last from America—and Evening visits from Count Jenison, and Mr Fisher— I was obliged as I almost always am, to snatch quarters of an hour, the day and evening through to write a letter.

22. Morning visits from Mr Montreal, Mr Harris and Mr Saltus— The last of these Gentlemen told me that he expected to dispatch an express to Captain Bates at Riga to-morrow, and I gave him the letters I had prepared to send by Commodore Bainbridge, whose departure is deferred for a few days.— I paid Evening Visits to Madame Bezerra, and at Mr Krehmer’s— The former was not at home— I also called on Commodore Bainbridge and Mr: Colhoun— I came home about eleven— Mr Ingraham and Mr Roberts had been here— I read the first and part of the second Book of Plato’s Republic; with which I am charmed— Not as a plan for a Government, but as a disquisition upon Justice—

23. Mr: Montreal called upon me again this morning— He told me that the young man whom he introduced to me last week, was a son of my old friend Mr Peyron— I had not caught his name, when he came with him— In the Evening we had a visit from Baron Blome— I was employed every leisure moment of the day and Evening in writing letters to send by Commodore Bainbridge, who wrote me a note, fixing upon next Sunday as the day upon which he intends to leave the City— This day commences the third year of our present residence at St: Petersburg.

24. Finished reading the first Volume of the French Translation of Plato’s Republic. I think it an excellent Translation; and the very few notes of the Translator make me wish that he had been more liberal of his reflections— I had a long visit from Count Bussche, who gave me some information, in return for some that I had given him the last time he called upon me— We had also some discussion upon certain political topics; particularly relating to the probability of a Peace between Russia, and the Porte, by the means of England— Mr Fisher dined with us.— In the Evening we had a visit from the Chevalier Bezerra, and his Lady— I wrote nothing this day, which like too many others slip’d away, I scarcely know how, and was gone while I was preparing for my suitable occupation.

25. I received this Morning from Count Romanzoff the Courier’s Passport for Commodore Bainbridge which I had yesterday requested— I accomplished in the course of the day and Evening the writing of one letter, and received two— Taking my usual round before dinner I met the Emperor upon the Fontanka— He observed I had no gloves on my hands, and asked me if I was not cold without them— I told him I had accustomed myself to going without gloves, and seldom wore any, but in extreme cold weather: he appeared to be much surprized at this, for the wearing of gloves, or of mittens is so universal in this Country, that I suppose it struck him as oddly to see a man with bare hands, as it would have been had he met me bare footed— In general the Emperor is extremely quick, and particular in observing slight peculiarities in dress— He asked me whether there was an Officer of the Navy of the United States now here— I told him there was; but he was on the point of his departure— He enquired what had brought him here— I said his private Affairs— Had he come as Master of a Merchant Vessel?— he had not— Merely as a traveller then?— As a traveller, upon business of his own, and with a permission from the Government.— Was it customary, under the Government of the United States, to allow their naval Officers, to go as Masters of Merchant Vessels?— Sometimes, when they were upon furlough— Most of our naval Officers had been taken, from among the Captains of Vessels in the merchant service— That, he said differed from the English practice— In England Officers of the Navy were some times allowed to sail in merchant Vessels, but he believed they were never taken from Merchant-men, to be Marine-Officers— I said they had an extensive system for the regular education of Officers to the service of the Navy; which on a smaller scale we now had also— But that our navy itself was a recent institution, and in the origin it was necessary to take its Officers, among the persons best qualified for the service, which were obviously mariners experienced in the merchant-service— He said it was his physician (Dr: Wiley) who had told him that there was an American Officer here— I suppose he also knew that I had applied to Count Romanzoff for a Passport for him, but of this he said nothing— I met Dr Wiley the other Evening at Commodore Bainbridge’s lodgings— He was attending him professionally—under an attack of rhumatism— In the course of my walk I met General Pardo, who told me of the Courier arrived last Evening from General Kutuzoff, with advices of a splendid Victory over the Turks— The Chevalier de Bray paid us an evening visit, and gave us the same information.

26. Extraordinary cold weather, even in this Climate— Reaumurs Thermometer at 8. degrees below 0. It is the Empress-Mother’s birth-day; but it was kept at Gatschina— Nothing in the City— I could not accomplish one short letter to Mr Eustis the Secretary at War, but left it unfinished for to-morrow— Messrs: Bainbridge, Blanchard, Boit, Colhoun, David, Ecky, Harris and his nephew, Fisher, Ingraham, Plummer, Roberts, Rogers, Saltus and Smith of Boston dined, and some of them spent part of the Evening here— Messrs Blodget, O. Plummer, Haven and Hollins were invited but did not come— Mr Bezerra called upon me late in the Evening, and brought a packet to be sent by Commodore Bainbridge who intends to go, to-morrow. I could not write in the Evening; and read only the newspapers.

27. I was engaged all the morning, in preparing and making up my letters and dispatches to be sent by Commodore Bainbridge— He left the City at four O’Clock this afternoon— We had visitors almost the whole of the Evening— Mr Colombi and Mr Seir, and afterwards Mr Woodward— Mr Colombi informed us that the Bridge was carried away this Evening about 7. O’Clock— The weather continues severely cold, with a Clear sky, and North-East Wind.— I am still interrupted in the series of Letters that I had undertaken— I read Robinson’s character of St: Paul, and a Sermon upon Veracity in the English preacher.

28. The cold weather continues; the Canals are all frozen over, and the river is full of floating ice— All the Bridges are gone— Mr: David my old schoolmate called upon me for a Passport, which I gave him— He is going in a few days to Gothenburg, and perhaps to England, to embark for America— Mr Harris also paid me a long morning visit— We were the whole Evening without interruption; and I wrote letters to Mr Erving and Mr Everett.

29. There was the most violent and the longest Snow-storm that I have known in Russia, which continued the whole of this day and Evening, and confined me to the house— General Watzdorf and Mr Fisher spent the Evening with us— The General told me of a Lyceum that is to be opened next Thursday at Czarsko-Zelo, but he knew not what it was— I barely began a letter to my father.— This morning I finished reading the Abbé Grou’s Translation of Plato’s Republic; a work to which I must return again— I never before read it with so much attention, and it is full of so much excellent Instruction that it cannot be too deeply impressed
impressed upon the mind— It is undoubtedly mixed with some gross absurdities, with some miserable sophistry, and with some whimsical oddities— The general defect of the Republic is, that as a theory of Government it undertakes to govern too much— It leaves too little to individual Will— Its features are too arbitrary— As a moral treatise upon Justice, it has not sufficient unity of subject— The first idea of constituting an imaginary Republic, in order to ascertain the nature of Justice, flows naturally enough from the subject; for Justice is the great social virtue, which should govern us in our Relations with other men— But after having erected his fabric, Plato, or Socrates, adheres too much to it, and does not enough remember the purpose for which he raised it— He returns indeed at the close of the tenth Book to the noble proposition with which he began, that Justice is to be practiced, though it should be ever so unfortunate, and even in famous in the erring judgment of mankind, but he has not pointed the application of his political Institutions to his moral principle. Hence it is that this work is always considered as a theory of Government, and not as a mere moral Dissertation— His community of goods and of women, is a melancholy proof of the weakness of the human mind— His exclusion of the Poets, is founded upon a sophistical train of reasoning; and his calculation that a king is 729 times happier than a tyrant, is ridiculous— But with these errors the mixture of wise opinions, exalted sentiment, sublime morality is so predominant that it is scarcely proper to mention them— They are fit to be meditated upon more maturely, which I intend— The form of the work is pleasing, though it is too long for a Dialogue— The Scenery is well laid— The Sophist Thrasymachus rather too soon dispatched, for the violence with which he commences, and the two brothers Glaucon and Adimantus perhaps not sufficiently discriminated in their characters— Plato never represents himself to have been present at any of these dialogues—in the Phaedo, he expressly says that he was not there; because he was sick— River stop’d this Evening.

30. The Snow continued this day, but the storm of wind abated, and I walked on the Quay, where the river was fixed but not yet passable— I dined with Mr Fisher, who had a Company of one or two and twenty-persons, almost all Americans— Mr Bentzon, Mr Von Essen, and Mr Haggart were among them— I came immediately home; and early in the Evening— Mr Lesseps and Mr Prevost paid us visits which occupied the whole Evening— Mr: Prevost brought me Chateaubriand’s Itinéraire— This morning I read the first Book of Grou’s Translation of Plato’s Laws— Of this Book I believe there is no English Translation— I wrote very little.

31. Morning visits from Mr Parker and Mr Norman— Mr Plummer and Mr Slade— Mr Harris; and Mr Fisher. The two first of these Gentlemen are going to Gothenburg and further, with Mr David and Mr Joseph Austin— They came for Passports which I gave them. Mr Slade brought me a letter and packet of Newspapers from Mr J. S. Smith in London, with a packet for Mr Patterson and several other letters— Mr Fisher had been over to the Island to see Mr Blodget who is very dangerously ill with a fever— This was the first day that he could go over since Sunday; the river not having been passable before— I went with him to the Glass-Manufactory which is just beyond the Monastery of St: Alexander Newsky— It was so late that we could see only a small part of the works which they carry on— The most curious part of them is the making of looking glasses—four of which had been cast this morning before we went there— They shewed us the manner of coating the glasses with Mercury and Tin, and they were at work in polishing a number of them which is performed with a Steam-engine; an invention of prodigious effect, in its application to manufactures— They also make here decanters, wine glasses, tumblers, and coloured-glass dishes and vases of various kinds— I saw the various works of blowing, colouring, cutting and gilding but we were obliged to go over the whole in the space of half an hour; and I know not how to describe even what I saw— I wish I could visit a manufacture once a week, and spent three hours at every visit— If I learnt nothing else by it, I should have a perpetual lesson of humility in the consciousness of my ignorance from which it would not suffer me to escape— This manufacture belongs to the Crown and I hope to see it again— We returned home
about 6. O’Clock, but Mr Fisher, could not stay to dine with us, being engaged to go over again to see Mr Blodget. We had no Company in the Evening, and I pass’d it reading English and American Newspapers.

Day. My course of occupation is now so regular that its principal variety results from the successive change of the Seasons. During the present month we have removed our residence from the Country, back into the City; but this has made very little difference in my mode of life— I now begin to read as soon as the morning light allows, and read about two hours before rising from bed— About 10. I rise and continue reading untill near eleven when we breakfast— From that time untill four in the afternoon, I receive visits, and write as I find opportunity— Walk an hour—dine—and pass the Evening untill midnight in writing and with visitors; or sometimes, though very rarely in paying visits— About midnight I go to bed— The Evening writing is involuntary, but necessary— The continual interruptions which I have then and the morning, make it indispensable to seize any moments that I can find.
